Description: Egyptian terracotta female figure holding stave or pillar. Mould-made and hollow with square vent in simple back. Head and part of base missing. Soft white (gypsum?) coating preserved on some areas. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with black core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably local production. Possibly a depiction of the goddess Demeter. Examples with similar drapery style have been dated to the 1st century BC (Torok 1995, 41-2, nos 29-30), though other Egyptian examples have been dated to the Roman period (Dunand 1990, 50, nos 67-8). However Gutch, in Hogarth’s Naukratis interim report, dates this to c.250BC ( Gutch in Hogarth 1899, pl. 12, no. 76). Dunand, F. 1990. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités Égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte. Paris. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Roma.
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 84, no. 78, pl. XII, no. 78)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.236) (Phase 1)
